title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" focuses on coordinating cybersecurity efforts between state and local governments with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance coordination between the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center and state/local governments in identifying and addressing cybersecurity vulnerabilities and risks. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 enhances coordination between the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center and state/local governments to identify information security protections for data collected or maintained by government entities or organizations. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to enhance coordination between the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center and state/local governments to provide information security tools and resources via a web portal. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to coordinate with State and local officials to ensure effective implementation of information security tools and provide cybersecurity training to government analysts and operators. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to provide technical cybersecurity training, privacy, and civil liberties training to State and local governments, and offer operational and technical assistance upon request for implementing cybersecurity tools and policies. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 provides technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security tools, products, resources, policies, guidelines, and procedures. This includes deploying technology for continuous diagnosis and mitigation of cyber threats, compiling and analyzing data on information security, and conducting targeted activities. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 provides technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security measures, including conducting targeted operational evaluations and assisting in developing vulnerability disclosure policies. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to ensure that State and local governments are aware of information security standards and resources developed by federal agencies. This includes training on privacy and civil liberties. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 focuses on ensuring the security and resiliency of Federal civilian information systems through privacy and civil liberties training that aligns with the Department's Fair Information Practice Principles. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to limit the receipt, retention, use, and disclosure of cybersecurity information related to specific persons, minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties, and ensure data integrity. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties by ensuring data integrity through the prompt removal of obsolete or erroneous personal information unrelated to cybersecurity risks. It also includes requirements to safeguard proprietary or business-sensitive cyber threat indicators and defensive measures. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to safeguard proprietary or business-sensitive information, protect confidentiality of cyber threat indicators, and ensure constitutional, legal, and privacy protections are observed. Congressional oversight is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 requires congressional oversight within 2 years of enactment to assess the activities and effectiveness of cybersecurity measures. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center will gather feedback from State and local governments on information security activities. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015, as attested by Clerk Karen L. Haas.
